awd_titl_txt: Dynamics of Excited States in DNA Strands and DNA-Silver Nanoclusters
awd_abstract_narration:
Silver ions (Ag+) can bind to the nitrogen and oxygen atoms in DNA giving rise to unusual and interesting molecular structures. DNA acts as a scaffold that precisely controls the positions of individual silver ions.  When another chemical reagent is added to provide electrons to the Ag+ ions, the array of Ag+ ions in the DNA become small clusters containing no more than a few dozen metal atoms. These miniscule clusters have remarkable optical properties, including for example fluorescence. Fluorescence is a process by which a molecule absorbs light at one wavelength and shortly afterwards emits light of another color.  This is a property that macroscopic silver objects do not possess. Their fluorescence properties makes these silver clusters attractive for sensing and imaging applications. However, despite widespread interest in these clusters, very little is known about what controls their light emission. In this project funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-A) program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Bern Kohler of The Ohio State University and students working under his direction are investigating DNA-metal assemblies that are excited by short laser pulses (a few hundred femtoseconds, where a femtosecond is one quadrillionth of one second).   The Kohler team observes how the color of the light emitted from the silver clusters depends on the color and time interval of the impinging laser pulse.  Under some conditions, no light is emitted at all.  These studies are revealing the mysteries of how light energy is absorbed by small metal clusters, and either emitted again as light or dissipated into the clusters' surroundings. The undergraduate and graduate students involved in this project are gaining experience in state-of the-art laser techniques, and the kinds of analysis needed to solve problems at the interface of spectroscopy and nanoscience. This multidisciplinary training is important for upholding the nation's workforce of scientists. 

This project targets fundamental understanding of excited electronic states formed by UV and visible excitation of DNA-metal complexes and nanostructures. Silver ions coordinate to the nitrogen and oxygen atoms of the nucleobases, giving rise to metal-mediated base pairs and a rich variety of self-assembled structures. Reduction of the bound silver ions produces compact metal nanostructures containing small numbers of silver atoms with remarkable, but poorly understood photophysical properties. Using femtosecond spectroscopy, nonradiative and radiative decay pathways are being observed and characterized in mononucleotide-metal ion complexes and their self-assembled nanostructures, and in DNA-hosted silver nanoclusters. Time-domain measurements are employed to develop a comprehensive photophysical model of silver nanoclusters. Fundamental understanding of the electronic interactions between DNA and metals can provide new insights into hybrid organic-inorganic interfaces that are attractive for controlling the separation and recombination of photogenerated carriers and redox equivalents.   The study of few-atom noble metal nanoclusters by ultrafast spectroscopy promises to accelerate societally beneficial advances in science and technology.  The ability to control and manipulate the excited states of metal nanoparticles could advance the fields of chemical imaging and sustainable energy production.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The double helical structure of the DNA molecule is an iconic and familiar image. Less well known is that DNA can form very different structures when metal ions are present, when the pH is changed, or when multiple DNA strands interact with one another or with proteins. Some of these altered structures play a role in disease or in how genes function, while others are of interest for applications that seek to exploit their unusual optical or catalytic properties. In this project, two classes of self-assembled structures formed by DNA and metal ions were studied using pulsed lasers. The work extended approaches that have been used previously to study how bare DNA strands interact with light to the complex DNA assemblies induced by metal ions. DNA contains four different nucleobases (A, G, C, T), which form the letters of the genetic alphabet. The nucleobases differ considerably in their ability to bind to diverse meteal ions. Changing the sequence of nucleobases in a DNA strand alters the kinds of structures that are formed with metal ions. In the first half of the project, DNA strands of different sequence were used to organize a small number of silver atoms into ultrasmall clusters that emit light strongly and have great potential for imaging. The laser investigations conducted during the first half of the study revealed strong interactions between the DNA nucleobases and the small clusters of silver atoms. This knowledge will aid future efforts to design brighter emitters or to tune their colors for sensing and imaging applications. In the second half of the project, DNA structures were studied in which every pair of nucleobases captures a single silver ion. Instead of lying flat as in the DNA double helix, these base pairs are strongly twisted in the manner of a propeller. The work revealed that when a DNA assembly with these twisted base pairs absorbs ultraviolet light, the energy added to the DNA decays thousands of times more slowly. These long-lived excitations, which are known as triplet excited states, have not been seen previously in DNA strands. The fundamental knowledge obtained from these studies benefits efforts to understand how DNA is damaged and how long-lived excited states may be used for harnessing energy from sunlight. The project provided training for several undergraduate and graduate students. Three undergraduate students acquired research experience and skills that allowed them to enroll in leading chemistry Ph.D. programs in the United States. Parts of the project formed the core of a graduate student's doctoral dissertation. The research findings were communicated through a dozen peer-reviewed publications in scientific journals. In addition, trainees presented their findings at scientific conferences. Finally, the project supported collaborations within and beyond the United States. Publications were co-authored with researchers from Furman University as well as with researchers at universities in China, Italy, and Spain. These global partnerships allowed the studies to progress more rapidly and provided valuable networking experience for the trainees and other participants.
